moves.1... b6: I like having my Bishop in charge of the long diagonal.
moves.2. d4 Bb7 3. Nc3 Nf6 4. Bd2 e6 5. e3 Be7: If I am lucky he will move his King Bishop out before shielding g2.
moves.6... d6 7. Be2 Nbd7 8. O-O O-O: We both seem to have reach an initial position in which we are somewhat comfortable.  (But having been away from the board for some months I was not really comfortable with any position!)
moves.9. b4: He begins struggle by undertaking some action on the Queenside.
moves.9... c5 10. bxc5 bxc5 11. Rb1: Apparently he does not like my long diagonal Bishop.
moves.12. Bc1: I am not sure where he was going with this repositioning move.
I still want my Bishop on this diagonal.
moves.16. Nd2: I felt this was preparatory to Qh5 but was comfortable I should be able to handle such an advance.
moves.16... Bf6 17. Bb2: To me, this did not seem all that good of a spot for his Bishop.
moves.17... d5 18. cxd5 Bxd5 19. Nb3: Perhaps a3 or a4 may have been better.  Though the Knight on b3 does provide some additional support for d4 I believe Black could play to give White isolated queenside pawns.
moves.19... cxd4 20. exd4 h6: This seemed appropriate to me for a number of reasons.
moves.21. Nc5: A miscalculation?  I usually look to see if the gift is real or a Trojan horse.  Since it appears to be real I never look a gift horse in the mouth.
moves.21... Nxc5 22. dxc5: Hmm, I guess it will be a gift Bishop.
moves.22... Rxb2: When I gain a material advantage, simplifying the position seems to be in order.
moves.23. Qc1 Rxb1 24. Qxb1 Bd4 25. Qb5 Qc7 26: This had been in my line of fire for several moves but now that my own "a" pawn has a guard I decided I could take it.
moves.27. c6 Bd5: I had no wish to leave my Bishop unprotected and I did not want his Queen to be able to reach the Kingside laterally.
moves.28. Qb4: I really did not expect him to do what I wanted him to do thus when he did so on this move I was rather happily surprised!!
moves.28... Qf4: Now I draw a bead on his c1 Rook and threaten a discovered attack on his Queen as well as posing a mating attack against his King.
moves.29. Qe1: A limited defense ( I don't believe an adequate defensive move was available.)
moves.29... Bxf2+: Adding at least the exchange to my material advantage.
moves.30. Qxf2 Qxc1+ 31. Bf1: Perhaps Qf1 would have been better but at this point the position and the game was really Black's.
moves.31... a5: Moving the pawn out of harm's way.
moves.32. Qb6 a4: And again.  (It is also moving toward its queening square.)
moves.33. c7: So White does the same.  However, at the moment White's queening square is under the observation of both Black's Rook and Queen.
moves.33... Bc4: OUCH!!!!  The power of the pin is demonstrated rather painfully to White.
moves.34. Qf2: While this prevents the immediate mate, the forthcoming piece exchange will leave Black with an unstoppable "a" file pawn.

gameName: First complete game after my computer crash hiatus.
